summary: This is a search terms report from the case US v. Epstein, detailing the number of documents responsive to specific search terms. It provides statistics on term hits within a large document set, indicating the volume of evidence related to names, entities, and keywords associated with Jeffrey Epstein and his network.

events.title: Search Terms Report Generated
events.description: A report detailing the responsiveness of documents to specific search terms in the case US v. Epstein was generated.

keyFacts: The searchable document set contained 1,615,584 total documents, with 1,139,816 documents (over 70%) containing hits for the specified search terms.
The term 'epstein' had the highest number of unique document hits at 77,261, indicating it is the most prevalent keyword in the collection.

Names like 'Andrew' (16,341 hits), 'David' (39,898 hits), 'Ghislaine' (3,225 hits), 'Klein' (23,766 hits), and 'Leon' (30,748 hits) show significant prevalence in the document set, suggesting their importance to the investigation.
Terms associated with travel and assets, such as 'Boeing' (9,609 hits), 'Gulfstream' (5,564 hits), 'Jet' (10,150 hits), and 'Lolita' (related term 'Log' has 23,871 hits), appear frequently.

Terms suggestive of alleged criminal activity, including 'massage' (9,190 hits), 'masseuse' (4,515 hits), 'Slave' (686 hits), and 'vibrator' (280 hits), are present in the search terms, indicating these concepts were part of the investigative focus.
